instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message: This board is getting 5V on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TA_VBUS_CONN</SIGNAL>. It got hit pretty hard on the bottom left corner of the back of the board. A few other spots on the back also. Top side looks clean. I included pre-ultrasonic pics. I've spent a long time cleaning up that terrible area near <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>. Replaced everything looked bad and check for continuity and shorts. Everything looks good now. Not sure what's not working correctly here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present at 3.3 volts? If yes, see if it bootloops any of the ports. If no, check for a short. If no short, inject 3.3 volts into that line and see if you get any current draw. If you do have a short, relieve the short

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message:
Looks like SMC cannot communicate with all 4 USBC controllers.
Check if something change testing all ports with charger.
You may note something heats, just test.
If the same, then start measuring resistance to ground on all power rails of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 and UB300/400.
Of course, check first voltage and resistance to ground at F7000 and L6900.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message: Okay, will do. Is <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> involved in that process? I'm guessing it is and that was the area that was hit the hardest. I've tried to clean it up as much as possible and replaced any bad components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message:
• 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

• Can't find anything different when powering the 4 USB-C ports.
• 5.2V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>.
• 4V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL>.
• No shorts on F7000 (.320 in diode mode) or L6900 (.344 in diode mode).
• .138 on all 4 power rail fuses.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message:
"2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>"
There is the problem.
Resistance to ground, exact value on ohm scale?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message: Yes check for short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. If no short, as often is the case, I would inject voltage into <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and see if anything pulls current. In my experience, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is often the culprit

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message:
2.7kΩ to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. My good board is measuring 2.8kΩ.

I wasn't aware that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> would still be produced even if DCIN is at 5.2V and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> is at 4V.

PPBUS is at .320 in diode mode vs a good board at .430.

All 4 USB-C controllers are measuring fine.

I've checked everything else in all of the damaged areas and anything else that seems like it could be an issue. I can't find anything off compared to my good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message: All of that is normal. The reason <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is being pulled down is likely because either the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> or one of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips is pulling it down. In my experience, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> pulls it down most often. I would inject 3 volts into <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and monitor if anything pulls current. Your PPBUS being slightly low could point to the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>. One of those is likely pulling down <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and DCIN.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on DC-In
threads.message:
Your case is not simple. You don't have a pure short, nor low value to ground on that line.
Very likely nothing gets hot injecting tension.
You may have luck if is an IC and enters in some kind of avalanche when injecting voltage, even if no low ohmic value there.
If not, you can inject voltage and wait 10min (maybe more) and try to find at least an area with few degrees more than the rest of board. Remove CPU heatsink in such case.
A thermal camera can help in this case. Or use the lips, instead of fingers, to check board temp...
